entry.title: Re: CONVERT_KEY_NOT_MAPPED issue in I_SALESORDERTP BDEF
entry.content:
You need to fill ls_so_temp_key with the key before calling to CONVERT KEY.

Try with this:

MODIFY ENTITIES OF i_salesordertp
  ENTITY salesorder
  CREATE FIELDS ( salesordertype salesorganization distributionchannel organizationdivision soldtoparty )
  WITH VALUE #( ( %cid = 'cid1'
                  %data = VALUE #(
                    salesordertype = iv_sales_ordertype "'YSV'
                    salesorganization = iv_sales_organization "'5PUS'
                    distributionchannel = iv_distributionchannel "'10'
                    organizationdivision = iv_organizationdivision "'P1'
                    soldtoparty = iv_soldtoparty "'0000151520'
                  ) ) )
  CREATE BY \_item AUTO FILL CID
  FIELDS ( product
           requestedquantity
* plant
         )
  WITH VALUE #( ( %cid_ref = 'cid1'
                  %target = VALUE #( FOR ls_items IN lt_items (
                    product = ls_items-product
                    requestedquantity = ls_items-requestedquantity
* plant = '8359'
                  ) ) ) )
  MAPPED DATA(ls_mapped)
  FAILED DATA(ls_failed)
  REPORTED DATA(ls_reported_modify).

DATA: ls_so_temp_key TYPE STRUCTURE FOR KEY OF i_salesordertp.

COMMIT ENTITIES BEGIN
  RESPONSE OF i_salesordertp
  FAILED DATA(ls_save_failed)
  REPORTED DATA(ls_save_reported).

ls_so_temp_key-%cid = 'cid1'.
CONVERT KEY OF i_salesordertp FROM ls_so_temp_key TO DATA(ls_so_final_key).

COMMIT ENTITIES END.

entry.title: Re: Idoc set up by Basis
entry.content:
The process starts with creating a new logical system using transaction BD54. This logical system is then assigned to the required client via SCC4 or SCC43, establishing the technical foundation for ALE communication.

Since a standard message type with its corresponding standard IDoc type is used, several required Customizing steps are already delivered by SAP. These include:

  • WE82 for assigning the message type to the IDoc type

  • WE57 for assigning the function module to the message type and IDoc type

The final step is maintaining the partner profile using WE20. Here, the communication partner is created, the relevant message type is maintained in the inbound parameters, and the appropriate process code is assigned within the message type. The process code details are maintained directly in the message type configuration.

Once these steps are completed, the ALE configuration is finished and ready for use. Overall, this is a solid example of implementing a stable ALE interface using standard SAP functionality with minimal custom development.

entry.title: SAP Master Data Governance in a Two-Tier ERP Landscape with HQ & Subsidiary Approach
entry.content:
Many organizations today operate in a 2-Tier ERP landscape. The typical setup is straightforward:
The headquarters (HQ) runs SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud, while regional or newly acquired subsidiaries run SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud for speed, simplicity, and lower operational overhead.

This model works well from a system perspective‚Äîbut it also asks some questions.
When each system manages its own master data, inconsistencies appear. Customers get duplicated, product hierarchies drift apart, and group-level reporting becomes harder with every rollout.

This is exactly where SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) fits into the picture.

Why Master Data Governance Becomes Important

In a 2-Tier environment, ERP systems are technically independent but business data is shared.
Customers, suppliers, products, and financial structures must mean the same thing everywhere.

Without a governance layer, organizations often experience:

  • Multiple versions of the same customer or supplier
  • Different product definitions across regions
  • Manual reconciliation during reporting and audits
  • Growing effort to onboard new subsidiaries

SAP MDG addresses this by introducing structure and ownership around master data‚Äîwithout taking flexibility away from local businesses.

How SAP MDG can be Used in a Private‚ÄìPublic Cloud Setup

In this landscape, SAP MDG runs at HQ on S/4HANA Private Cloud.
It becomes the central place where master data is created, validated, and approved.

Subsidiaries on S/4HANA Public Cloud do not manage governance themselves. Instead, they:

  • Receive approved master data from HQ
  • Use it operationally
  • Maintain only a small set of permitted local attributes

A simple principle guides the design:

Create and control master data centrally, consume it locally.

This keeps global standards intact while allowing subsidiaries to remain agile.

High-Level Architecture View

At a conceptual level, the setup consists of three clear layers:

  • Governance Layer (HQ ‚Äì Private Cloud)
    SAP MDG defines rules, workflows, and approvals for master data.
  • Integration Layer
    Standard SAP APIs ensure secure and consistent data distribution.
  • Consumption Layer (Subsidiaries ‚Äì Public Cloud)
    Subsidiaries receive governed master data and enrich it only where allowed.

Why This Matters for S/4HANA Public Cloud

S/4HANA Public Cloud is designed to stay clean, standardized, and upgrade-safe.
SAP MDG supports this philosophy by ensuring that only high-quality, compliant master data enters these systems.

As a result, organizations benefit from:

  • Fewer data-related issues in Public Cloud
  • Faster onboarding of new subsidiaries
  • More reliable enterprise reporting
  • Lower long-term data maintenance effort

Conclusion :

In a 2-Tier ERP landscape with S/4HANA Private Cloud at HQ and S/4HANA Public Cloud at subsidiaries, SAP Master Data Governance is not just a technical solution‚Äîit is a strategic foundation.

By placing governance at the center and distribution at the edge, organizations achieve:

  • Global consistency without slowing down local teams
  • A scalable ERP model for growth and acquisitions
  • Long-term alignment with SAP‚Äôs cloud strategy

Strong master data governance ensures that as systems evolve, data remains stable, trusted, and ready for the future.

entry.title: Issue with Electronic Credit Notes ‚Äì Missing Period Dates and Email Mapping (Colombia Localization)
entry.content:
Hello,

We would like to request your support regarding an issue we are currently facing with electronic credit notes in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition ‚Äì Colombia localization.

At the moment, we are actively working on electronic invoicing, and we have already validated that standard electronic invoices are being generated and sent correctly to the tax authority, without any issues. These documents are being processed successfully and are compliant.

However, now that we are starting to work specifically with electronic credit notes, we have identified errors during the generation and submission of the electronic document to the Colombian tax authority (DIAN).

Issue description

When the electronic credit note is sent to the tax authority, the following errors are returned:

  1. Missing period dates
    The XML file generated by the system is not populating certain mandatory fields related to:

    • Start date of the billing period

    • End date of the billing period

    These dates seem to be required by the tax authority and associated with some part of the document, but we are unable to identify where these fields should be captured or derived from within the credit note document in the system. The system does not appear to recognize or populate these values in any section of the XML.

  2. Customer / Vendor email not mapped
    We are also receiving an error indicating that the email address is not informed for the customer or vendor involved in the credit note.

    However, we have validated that:

    • The email address is correctly maintained in the Business Partner master data.

    • Despite this, the email is not being mapped or reflected in the electronic document, resulting in the error message from the tax authority.

Request for support

We would appreciate your help to understand:

  • Why these fields (period start and end dates) are not being populated in the XML for electronic credit notes.

  • From which configuration or document fields these values should be derived.

  • Why the customer/vendor email, although maintained in master data, is not being mapped into the electronic document.

  • If there are specific configuration points related to Document & Reporting Compliance / Statutory Reporting for Colombia that should be reviewed or adjusted for credit notes.

We would especially appreciate guidance from someone with experience in Colombia localization and electronic document compliance configuration.

Evidence

Attached you will find:

  • Screenshots of the system errors.

  • The messages returned by the tax authority.

  • Supporting evidence showing the master data configuration.

Thank you in advance for your support. We look forward to your guidance to resolve these issues as soon as possible.

As outlined in KBA 2596214 - How to maintain Super, Cloud, and User Administrator S-user IDs listed in My Important Contacts - SAP for Me

To add a Super Administrator, an existing Super Administrator must provide all authorizations to another S-user ID. Tip: Follow KBA 1614304 to copy or clone their own authorizations.

entry.title: YATIRIMTESVIK scenario support through Extensibility in DRC T√ºrkiye
entry.content:
This blog post introduces a guide on how to implement the new legal requirement released by GIB (*******) for invoices issued under a valid Investment Incentive Certificate (Yatƒ±rƒ±m Te≈üvik Belgesi ‚Äì YTB) through Developer Extensibility for Document and Reporting Compliance T√ºrkiye in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.


Background 
We have already published a Developer Extensibility for Document and Reporting Compliance T√ºrkiye in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud on how S/4HANA Public Cloud customers can leverage developer extensibility to modify content of XMLs produced during electronic invoice submissions, pertaining to specific business and legal requirements.

Note for: SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud and ECC environments: 

In SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud and ECC environments, the exact same process exists through extensibility, however the BAdi implementation would have to be done for EDOC_ADAPTOR instead of EDOC_ADAPTOR_CLOUD.

What‚Äôs New? 
GIB has published a legal requirement pertaining to invoices issued under valid Investment Incentive Certificate which impacts a few companies on 21st November, 2025. In this blog we would aim to address the requirement through the learnings of the previous blog highlighted in the background.

What‚Äôs the technical specifications of the requirement? 
Currently system does not automatically determine whether a billing or finance document is YTB-related or not. The customer must explicitly indicate that the invoice belongs to a YTB investment project and provide the necessary values. As part of the legal requirement authority following is an easy requirement with an UBL (Universal Business Language, an ISO standard XML) representation:

  • New Profile IDs
    • YATIRIMTESVIK ‚Äì for eInvoicing scenarios 
    • EARSIVFATURA ‚Äì for eArchive scenarios 
  • New Invoice Type Codes under each invoicing scenarios
    • YATIRIMTESVIK ‚Äì for eInvoicing scenarios.
      • SATIS ‚Äì Sales invoices
      • ISTISNA ‚Äì Exception invoices
      • IADE ‚Äì Refund or Return invoices
    • EARSIVFATURA ‚Äì for eArchive scenarios
      • YTBSATIS ‚Äì consumer/eArchive sales invoice 
      • YTBISTISNA ‚Äì consumer/eArchive exception invoices
      • YTBIADE ‚Äì consumer/eArchive refund/return invoices
  • Mapping of new identification tag - ContractDocumentReference 
<ContractDocumentReference>
  • ID field should be the filled up with the incentive certificate number
    • schemeID of this would be "YTBNO"
  • IssueDate should be filled up with the investment certificate date in DD/MM/YYYY format 
  • Adjustments to existing tag - TaxTotal 
<TaxTotal>
  • The waived VAT amount should be shown in XPath TaxTotal/TaxSubtotal/TaxAmount only if profileID is YATIRIMTESVIK with invoice type value is ISTISNA, or profileID is EARSIVFATURA with invoice type value is YTBISTISNA.
  • Reason codes similar to tax exemption reason codes have been introduced as part of the technical structure from GIB available at their website. These reason codes have to be filled in XPath TaxTotal/TaxSubtotal/TaxCategory/TaxExemptionReasonCode.
  • Subsequently new reason code descriptions have also been introduced as part of the technical structure which should go in the XPath TaxTotal/TaxSubtotal/TaxCategory/TaxExemptionReason corresponding the reason code filled in above step.
  •  
  • Adjustments to existing tag - InvoiceLine 
<InvoiceLine>
  • For YTB related scenarios the XPath tag InvoiceLine/Item/CommodityClassification/ItemClassificationCode should be filled with 01, 02, 03, or 04 in case of the scenario of profile ID of YATIRIMTESVIK/EARSIVFATURA.
    • In case the ItemClassificationCode is 01 (Machine Equipment), and reason code in TaxExemptionReason is 308 as per the legal requirement, then
      • XPath tag InvoiceLine/Item/Name should be filled with machin name
      • XPath tag InvoiceLine/Item/ItemInstance/Name should be filled with Machine ID.
      • XPath tag InvoiceLine/Item/ItemInstance/ProductTraceID should be filled with the Machine Sequence Number/Equivalent details

How does a sample code looks like using Developer Extensibility?

The prerequisites, roles and BAdI Enhancement Implementation names have already been mentioned in our previous blog (details - Developer Extensibility for Document and Reporting Compliance T√ºrkiye in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud ).

Let's illustrate how this can be tailored to suit the above legal requirement.

    FIELD-SYMBOLS:
      <lfs_cs_doc_data>      TYPE edo_tr_inv_ubl_format_req,
      <fs_invoice_tab>       TYPE edo_tr_e_doc_turkey_invoic_tab,
      <fs_invoice_el>        TYPE edo_tr_e_doc_turkey_invoice_el,
      <fs_payment_means_tab> TYPE edo_tr_payment_means_tab,
      <fs_add_doc_ref>       TYPE edo_tr_additional_document_tab.

    ASSIGN COMPONENT 'DOC_DATA' OF STRUCTURE cs_output_data TO FIELD-SYMBOL(<lv_data>).
    IF <lv_data> IS ASSIGNED.
      IF iv_edoc_type = 'TR_BINV'. "Turkey Basic eInvoice
        IF iv_interface_id NE 'TR_GETSTATUS_REQ'.
          ASSIGN COMPONENT 'PARAMETERS' OF STRUCTURE cs_output_data TO <lv_data>.
          IF <lv_data> IS ASSIGNED.
            ASSIGN cs_output_data TO <lfs_cs_doc_data>.
            IF <lfs_cs_doc_data> IS ASSIGNED.
              ASSIGN <lfs_cs_doc_data>-parameters-package-elements TO <fs_invoice_tab>.
              IF <fs_invoice_tab> IS ASSIGNED.
                LOOP AT <fs_invoice_tab> ASSIGNING <fs_invoice_el>.
* This is just a sample implementation, you can decide on the conditional assignment based on your business needs.
                  <fs_invoice_el>-element_list-invoice-profile_id-base-base-content = 'YATIRIMTESVIK'.
                  <fs_invoice_el>-element_list-invoice-invoice_type_code-base-base-content = 'SATIS'.
" Filling up ContractDocumentReference
                  <fs_invoice_el>-element_list-invoice-contract_document_reference =
                    VALUE #( ( id-base-base-content = '1234567890'
                               id-base-base-scheme_id = 'YTBNO'
                               issue_date-base-content = '19990912' ) ).
" Filling up TaxTotal
                  <fs_invoice_el>-element_list-invoice-tax_total =
                    VALUE #( ( tax_subtotal =
                    VALUE #( ( tax_amount-base-content = '123.40'
                               tax_amount-base-currency_id = 'TRY'
                               tax_category-tax_exemption_reason_code-base-base-content = '308'
                               tax_category-tax_exemption_reason-base-base-content = 'Delivery of Investment Goods under Incentive Scheme 13/d' ) ) ) ).
" Filling up InvoiceLine
                  LOOP AT <fs_invoice_el>-element_list-invoice-invoice_line ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<lfs_invoice_line>).
                    <lfs_invoice_line>-item-commodity_classification = VALUE #( ( item_classification_code-base-base-content = '01' ) ).
                    READ TABLE <lfs_invoice_line>-item-commodity_classification ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<lfs_comm_class>)
                      WITH KEY item_classification_code-base-base-content = '01'.
                    IF sy-subrc IS INITIAL.
                      <lfs_invoice_line>-item-name-base-base-content = 'Machine Name'.
                      <lfs_invoice_line>-item-item_instance = VALUE #( ( serial_id-base-base-content = '9999999999'
                                                                         product_trace_id-base-base-content = '7878787878787878' ) ).
                    ENDIF.
                  ENDLOOP.
                ENDLOOP.
              ENDIF.
            ENDIF.
          ENDIF.
        ENDIF.
      ENDIF.
    ENDIF.

*Disclaimer - This is just a sample code; actual business conditions are not depicted through this.

Result: 

When you display the XML file of the electronic document in the‚ÄØeDocument Cockpit‚ÄØ(EDOC_COCKPIT) corresponding to the above invoicing scenario, you will see that the mentioned tags populated. Please note that based on actual submission of this document to authorized service provider, error handling and troubleshooting can be tackled.

Conclusion 
With recent enhancements to the T√ºrkiye Document and Reporting Compliance solution, SAP has made it significantly easier to cater to targeted and industry specific legal requirements in electronic document outputs. 

This improvement gives you more flexibility and helps ensure compliance with T√ºrkiye‚Äôs legal requirements. This blog is the first of the many blogs coming up to demonstrate legal requirements in an easy consumable way

entry.title: Re: Reduce SOFFCONT1 table size in database
entry.content:
In S/4HANA conversions and post‚Äëgo‚Äëlive phases, this is a very common misunderstanding.

Migrating documents from SOFFDB / SOFFCONT1 to BTP DMS (or any external content repository) does not automatically delete legacy content from SOFFCONT1. SAP treats migration and cleanup as two separate risk-controlled steps.

Be careful here ‚Äî deleting blindly can lead to attachment inconsistency and audit breaks.

What actually happens

  • Documents are copied to BTP DMS

  • Existing SOFFCONT1 entries remain unless explicitly reorganized

  • SAP does this intentionally to avoid data loss risk

Correct way to reduce SOFFCONT1 size

In high‚Äëvolume systems, SAP only supports cleanup via controlled reorganization:

  1. SAP Note 1634908 ‚Äì Reduce the number of entries in SOFFCONT1

    • This is the only SAP-supported approach

    • Uses RSBCS_REORG for SAPoffice cleanup

  2. Pre-check is mandatory

    • Verify active links via SRGBTBREL

    • Ensure no business objects still reference SOFFCONT1
      This is often missed and causes broken attachments post cleanup.

  3. Sequence matters

    • First: validate migration completeness

    • Second: freeze new attachment creation (if possible)

    • Third: run controlled reorganization
      Don‚Äôt jump to cleanup yet without validation.

Important S/4HANA risk considerations

  • SOFFCONT1 is memory-expensive in HANA

  • Large tables increase:

    • downtime risk during maintenance

    • HANA memory pressure

    • audit exposure if attachments disappear

Post‚Äëgo‚Äëlive, we usually see teams clean too early and discover missing finance or DMS attachments later ‚Äî that‚Äôs an audit and business risk.

Recommendation

Treat this as a content integrity exercise, not just disk cleanup.
Cleanup should be done only after link validation, preferably in a sandbox or QA run first.

entry.title: Re: Reduce SOFFCONT1 table size in database
entry.content:
In S/4 migrations and post go-live scenarios, this comes up quite often and people assume that once documents are moved to BTP DMS, SOFFCONT1 will automatically shrink. Unfortunately, that‚Äôs not how it works.

Be careful here: migrating or replicating documents to BTP DMS does not delete the original SAP office content from SOFFCONT1 by default. What you are seeing is expected behavior unless an explicit cleanup is executed. SAP keeps the original entries to avoid data loss and audit break scenarios.

In high-volume systems, SOFFCONT1 can remain very large even after content is available in DMS. This is often missed during conversion projects, and later it becomes a finance impact issue because the table still consumes disk and HANA memory.

Before jumping to cleanup, you need to confirm a few things. First, make sure the documents in BTP DMS are actually complete and readable for business users. Second, check if there are any legal retention or audit requirements that still require SAP office copies. Don‚Äôt assume everything can be deleted just because it‚Äôs ‚Äúmigrated‚Äù.

Once validated, the standard approach is to reduce SOFFCONT1 using SAP‚Äôs supported reorganization options. SAP Note 1634908 explains how to reduce entries in SOFFCONT1 using standard reports. This does not happen automatically as part of DMS migration.

Also, check whether your setup is using links (KPRO) or actual content move. In some scenarios, only references are created, and the original content is intentionally kept in SOFFCONT1 to avoid attachment inconsistency.

Post go-live, uncontrolled cleanup without validation can introduce audit issues or broken attachments, so this should be handled carefully, ideally first in a non-production system.

Short version: BTP DMS migration alone won‚Äôt reduce SOFFCONT1. Cleanup is a separate, controlled step, and you should treat it as a risk-managed activity, not a technical afterthought.

entry.title: Re: Document Compression in DMS.
entry.content:
In S/4 migrations and post go‚Äëlive setups, this usually surprises people, but it‚Äôs actually expected behavior. SAP DMS (Integration Option on BTP) stores content as‚Äëis it does not do automatic compression on upload. There‚Äôs no standard switch or configuration to enable compression at the DMS layer.

Be careful here because compression in SOFFCONT1 or SAP Content Server is a different model. BTP DMS stores objects with metadata, versions, checksums, and encryption overhead, so storage growth compared to HANA BLOB tables is normal. This is often missed during sizing and turns into a finance impact later.

If you want compression, it has to happen before upload (application layer or custom service) or via external tooling. Don‚Äôt jump to cleanup or assume something went wrong in migration ‚Äî this is more about architecture and pricing risk than a technical error.

entry.title: Re: Clarification about storage path- GOS_ATTACHMENT_LIST...
entry.content:
In S/4 migrations and also in classic ECC systems without a content server, GOS attachments created via GOS_ATTACHMENT_LIST_POPUP end up in SAPoffice. Be careful here, because this is often underestimated.

The actual binary data is stored in SOFFCONT1. Tables like SRGBTBREL only keep the link between the business object (for ME11/ME12) and the SAPoffice document. SOOD and SOFM hold header and metadata, but they don‚Äôt contain the file itself.

Post go-live, what usually causes storage pressure is that SOFFCONT1 grows silently with every attachment. If you want to assess impact, check the size of SOFFCONT1 directly in DB02. Don‚Äôt jump to cleanup yet though ‚Äî removing entries without understanding the linkage can lead to attachment inconsistency and audit issues.

entry.title: Re: issue "Unexpected Error" with test run of SAP report...
entry.content:
In S/4 migrations and even in ECC cleanups this ‚ÄúUnexpected error‚Äù in RSIRPIRL test run usually means the report hit a SAP office entry that has no valid physical content behind it. That‚Äôs exactly what Note 1773722 is hinting at.

Be careful here: test run in RSIRPIRL is not a full dry‚Äërun with detailed output. It only validates whether entries are technically reachable. If it encounters corrupted or already-orphaned SOFFCONT1 records, it just flags an unexpected error and moves on, without listing much detail.

Post go‚Äëlive we often see this in high‚Äëvolume systems where old attachments were deleted inconsistently. It does not automatically mean data loss during execution, but it does indicate attachment inconsistency already exists.

entry.title: Re: How to use GOS attachment URL in CDS view
entry.content:
In S/4 systems, GOS doesn‚Äôt really distinguish between ‚ÄúURL‚Äù and ‚Äúfile‚Äù at storage level. Even when you attach a URL via GOS, it‚Äôs still persisted as SAPoffice content and ends up in SOFFCONT1 as binary, not as plain text. This is often missed.

You can‚Äôt call function modules or do binary‚Äëto‚Äëtext conversion inside a CDS view, especially if the consumer is Datasphere. CDS is deliberately restricted, and virtual elements won‚Äôt help here either.

Be careful here: there is no standard table where GOS URLs are stored as clean text you can just select. If you need URLs in Datasphere, the usual approach is to change how they are created in the first place (store the URL as application data in your own table, not as a GOS attachment), or extract and convert them outside CDS (ABAP layer, ODP, or custom extraction). Otherwise you‚Äôre looking at a design limitation, not a missing join

entry.title: Re: Configuration to Include Freight Costs in Cost Estimate from PIR
entry.content:
It's not possible to determine different account for freight costs.

If the requirement is to determine overhead costs only on gross price, it's necessary to assign specific origin group in the customizing Assign Condition Types to Origin Groups for the gross price.

Then in the base setting of costing sheet, set base for the specific origin group.

entry.title: Re: DVM -->SAP SOFFCONT1 table limit exceeded and updates...
entry.content:
DVM does not recommend partitioning for SOFFCONT1 because partitioning does not actually reduce risk here. It only splits the table physically, but all inserts and reads still hit the same hot content paths. Once SOFFCONT1 grows into multi‚ÄëTB range, you‚Äôre exposed to update hangs, long commit times, and even mail/GOS outages. Be careful here ‚Äî partitioning would not have prevented the P1.

In practice, SOFFCONT1 is treated as SAPoffice content, not a classic application table. The only supported ways to reduce operational risk are SAPoffice reorganization (RSBCS_REORG) or relocating content to a content server. This is why DVM flags it as large but does not push a structural fix.

This is often missed: DVM is advisory, not preventive. It highlights size, but it won‚Äôt override application design limits. Once updates deactivate at ~4TB, you‚Äôre already in downtime‚Äërisk territory, so cleanup or offloading is the only safe path

entry.title: Re: Retreival of the Archived BCS (Buiness Communication...
entry.content:
In S/4 migrations and even in ECC, this is one of those areas where expectations don‚Äôt match reality.

There is no standard SAP-supported process to ‚Äúrestore‚Äù archived BCS / SOFFCONT1 data from a content server back into the SAP database. Once documents are relocated using RSIRPIRL, SAP treats that as a one‚Äëway move.

Be careful here: RSIRPIRL is designed to move content out of the database to reduce growth and risk, not to act as a reversible archive. Bringing data back into SOFFCONT1 would reintroduce database growth, potential audit inconsistencies, and in S/4 a real HANA cost impact.

In practice, post go-live scenarios rely on accessing

entry.title: S/4HANA Public Cloud ‚Äì Is it possible to add a 4th Receiver Role in Billing Document Output
entry.content:
Hello SAP Experts,

We are working on Billing Document Output Management in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud using BRF+ (Manage Output Determination Apps).

In Receiver determination (DT_RECEIVER), the system allows only the following standard roles for Billing Document:

  • RE (Bill-to Party)

  • AG (Sold-to Party)

  • RG (Payer)

Our business requirement is to print 4 copies of the Billing Invoice (Original, Duplicate, Triplicate, and Extra Copy).

We checked if an additional receiver role (for example, a 4th role or custom role) can be added in Output Management, but Public Cloud does not seem to support custom partner roles.

Question:

  • Is it technically possible in S/4HANA Public Cloud to add a 4th receiver role for Billing Document output determination?

  • If not, is the only supported approach to handle multiple invoice copies inside a single Adobe Form?

Any official confirmation or SAP note reference would be very helpful.

Thanks in advance.

entry.title: Re: Downtime Optimization Strategy to be considered - SUM DMO Migration
entry.content:
In S/4 migrations this lines up with what we usually see on large systems. Be careful though ‚Äî most downtime pain doesn‚Äôt come from SUM settings alone, it comes from data shape. Tables like SOFFCONT1, BALDAT, EDI* look harmless until downtime, then they explode export/import time and create real cutover risk.

One thing often missed is cleaning or relocating content before you start tuning R3load or infra. Otherwise you‚Äôre just throwing CPU at bad data and still risking overruns or audit issues post go‚Äëlive. Also watch network stability during import ‚Äî a few rc=110 or rc=104 events can silently add hours.

entry.title: Re: Reduce The Number of Entries Of Table SOFFCONT1
entry.content: In S/4 migrations and even post go-live, SOFFCONT1 growing to this size is pretty common if SAPoffice and GOS are still DB-based. Be careful here ‚Äî RSBCS_REORG only cleans unreferenced entries, it doesn‚Äôt really solve the growth problem long term, and the DB size won‚Äôt shrink automatically anyway

entry.title: Re: Where attachments are stored once Content Server is down
entry.content: In S/4 migrations and post go-live scenarios, this behavior usually means SAP is falling back to SAPoffice storage when the Content Server is not reachable. Be careful here: the attachments are temporarily written back into SAP tables, typically SOFFCONT1 (binary) with metadata in SOOD/SOFM, even though your storage category points to the content server. This is often missed and creates a silent data growth and audit risk if the outage goes unnoticed. Once the Content Server is back, you need to actively relocate those documents again using RSIRPIRL or the relevant GOS relocation report, otherwise they will stay in the database and increase SOFFCONT1 size. Don‚Äôt jump to cleanup yet‚Äîfirst confirm storage category behavior and error handling, otherwise you risk attachment inconsistency or data loss.

entry.title: Re: RFC to copy file from ECC to S4 Databse server
entry.content:
SCMS_DOC_COPY won‚Äôt help you here. It only copies a document between repositories inside the same system, not from ECC to S/4 via RFC. Making it RFC-enabled doesn‚Äôt change that, because the document ID you pass exists only in ECC, so S/4 will never find it.

If your goal is to move GOS attachments, the usual options are either use a shared content server (both ECC and S/4 pointing to the same repository), or write a custom solution: read the attachment content in ECC (via SOFFCONT1 / GOS APIs) using an RFC, then recreate the attachment in S/4 and rebuild the GOS link there. There is no standard RFC that copies files directly from ECC DB to S/4 DB.

entry.title: Re: How to store GOS attachments on an external content r...
entry.content: To store GOS attachments on an external content server, assign a new storage category to document class SOFFPHIO via SKPR08, map it to an external repository in OACT/OAC0, and use it for attachments. To move existing attachments from SOFFCONT1, run RSIRPIRL or RSGOS_RELOCATE_ATTA (per SAP Notes 389366 / 2293171).

entry.title: Re: Files need to transfer from SOFFPHF table to open tex...
entry.content: If the content server is temporarily unavailable, SAP may still allow attachments to be created, and those documents are then stored in the database, typically again in SOFFCONT1 or related SAPoffice tables. Once the content server is available again, these documents can be relocated using RSIRPIRL. There is no automatic fallback synchronization, so periodic relocation is required in such scenarios.

entry.title: Re: Store document from UI5 into SAP Archivelink
entry.content: From a practical point of view, you shouldn‚Äôt store the xstring directly in your own table. The usual approach is to stream the file from UI5 to the backend (for example via OData create_stream) and then use standard ArchiveLink APIs to persist it. In ABAP you can use function modules like ARCHIV_CREATE_TABLE / ARCHIVOBJECT_CREATE_TABLE or SCMS_AO_TABLE_CREATE, as long as your content repository is already configured in OAC0/OACT. Another common option is to first save the file as a GOS/SAPoffice attachment and then relocate it to the external ArchiveLink repository using RSGOS_RELOCATE_ATTA. This keeps the database small and relies on standard SAP mechanisms.

entry.title: Re: Archive SOFFCONT1 Table using SARA
entry.content:
In S/4 migrations and also in ECC, SOFFCONT1 cannot be archived via SARA. There is no SAP archiving object for this table, so standard data archiving is simply not supported. Be careful here ‚Äì this is often missed and people assume SARA can handle it like application tables.

Post go-live we usually see this table grow because it stores raw attachment content. Without moving data to a content server or deleting orphaned entries, there is no way to reduce the DB footprint without risk. Any custom archiving via ADK would mean touching binary content, which carries data loss and audit break risk, especially for finance or legal attachments.

In high-volume sy

entry.title: Re: Facing Issue in GOS Attachment for MM03
entry.content: This usually happens because the attachment is created but not correctly linked to the material object, so MM03 doesn‚Äôt show it. For GOS on materials, the object type must be BUS1001006 and the material number has to be in 18‚Äëchar internal format. Also make sure the folder, file extension, and header data are filled correctly before calling the link (ATTA). An easier and safer option is to use the standard class CL_GOS_DOCUMENT_SERVICE ‚Üí create_attachment, which handles the upload and linking automatically. Once the link exists in SRGBTBREL, the attachment will show up in MM03.

entry.title: Re: GOS attachment BADI implement GOS_SRV_SELECT
entry.content: This BAdI can only have one active implementation. In S/4HANA there is already a standard implementation (for example FIN_GOS_HTMLGUI) active, so when you try to activate your own one it gets deactivated with the message that it won‚Äôt be called. You usually can‚Äôt switch off the standard implementation, so the practical option is to enhance the standard class (implicit enhancement) and add your logic there instead of creating a separate BAdI implementation.

entry.title: Re: Preventing Negative Balances in Cost Centers in SAP P...
entry.content: Yes, in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, you can use Budget Availability Control and Situation Handling to trigger warnings or alerts when a cost center approaches or exceeds its budget. While the system doesn‚Äôt automatically block postings that drive balances negative, you can configure thresholds, notifications, and responsibility assignments to prevent surprises.  Check this blog  How Developer Extensibility lets you create your own Situation Handling Use Case from which, you can take the inputs under the heading "Cost center budget threshold exceeded"

ÈíàÂØπËØ•ÊÄªË¥¶ÁßëÁõÆ‰ΩøÁî®‰∫§ÊòìË¥ßÂ∏ÅUSDËøõË°åËøáË¥¶Ôºö

Êú™ÂãæÈÄâ‚Äú‰ªÖ‰ª•Êú¨Â∏ÅËÆ∞ÁöÑ‰ΩôÈ¢ù‚ÄùÂπ∂ËøõË°åË∑®Â∏ÅÁßçÊ∏ÖË¥¶‰∏öÂä°Ôºö

‰ºÅ‰∏öÂ≠òÂú®Ë∑®Â∏ÅÁßçÊ∏ÖË¥¶‰∏öÂä°ÔºåÂ¶ÇÂéüÂ∫îÊî∂/Â∫î‰ªòÂèëÁ•®ÁöÑ‰∫§ÊòìË¥ßÂ∏Å‰∏∫USDÔºå‰ΩøÁî®CNYÁõ¥Êé•ÈíàÂØπÂèëÁ•®ËøõË°åÊ∏ÖË¥¶

‰ºÅ‰∏öÂ≠òÂú®‰∫§ÊòìË¥ßÂ∏Å‰∏∫Â§ñÂ∏ÅÁöÑÂ∫îÊî∂Ë¥¶Ê¨æ/Â∫î‰ªòË¥¶Ê¨æ

ÈíàÂØπËØ•‰∫§ÊòìË¥ßÂ∏Å‰∏∫USDÂèëÁ•®Ôºå‰ΩøÁî®CNYËøõË°å‰ªòÊ¨æÂπ∂Ê∏ÖË¥¶Ôºö

Á≥ªÁªü‰ª•ÂéüÂßã‰∫§ÊòìË¥ßÂ∏Å‰Ωú‰∏∫‰ΩôÈ¢ù‰∫§ÊòìË¥ßÂ∏ÅÔºåÁ°Æ‰øùÂú®ËØ•Ë¥ßÂ∏ÅÂü∫Á°Ä‰∏äËøõË°åÊ∏ÖË¥¶Âπ≥Ë°°ËÆ°ÁÆó„ÄÇÂΩìÂ§ñÂ∏ÅÂèëÁ•®ÂèëÁ•®‰∏éÊú¨Â∏Å‰ªòÊ¨æ‰πãÈó¥Âõ†Ê±áÁéáÂèòÂä®‰∫ßÁîüÂ∑ÆÂºÇÊó∂Ôºå‰ΩôÈ¢ù‰∫§ÊòìË¥ßÂ∏ÅÁ°Æ‰øùÁ≥ªÁªüËÉΩÂ§üÊ≠£Á°ÆÂ§ÑÁêÜÊ±áÁéáÂ∑ÆÂºÇÔºåËá™Âä®ËÆ°ÁÆóÂπ∂ËøáË¥¶Ê±áÂÖëÊçüÁõä„ÄÇÂú®‰ΩôÈ¢ù‰∫§ÊòìË¥ßÂ∏Å‰∏ãÔºåÁ≥ªÁªüÁ°Æ‰øùÊ∏ÖË¥¶ÂêéÁöÑÂáÄ‰ΩôÈ¢ù‰∏∫Èõ∂ÔºåÂç≥‰Ωø‰ΩøÁî®‰∏çÂêåË¥ßÂ∏ÅËøõË°åÊ∏ÖË¥¶„ÄÇ

entry.title: Re: BI 2025 Requires license key generation
entry.content:
Regarding to your questions, kindly check the answer as following:

  • https://me.sap.com/licensekey/wizard

    ----> this link is the old version license key app's link, the new one is https://me.sap.com/licensekeys/installations/selectionscreen

    The road to find the license key app: Services & Support -> Overview -> Request license key -> license keys
  • It does not affect the existing license key, correct?
    ---->Yes, it will not affect the existing license keys.

  • Who can submit the request for new license key, is it the person with super admin privileges?
    ----> S-user who has "request license key" authorizations could be able to submit the request, not only the super admin.

  • Will it have the same number of concurrent licenses? and in how many environments can it be used?
    ---->Yes, it will the same number of concurrent licenses and how may environments you have.

entry.title: How inpeek Leveraged the SAP HANA Knowledge Graph Engine to Power a Chatbot for Structured Data
entry.content:
At inpeek , we are always looking for innovative ways to make our solutions smarter and more efficient. Our SaaS product Summarix supports us in managing CVs, project references, skills, customers, and more, enabling the seamless creation of call-for-tender documents. To make the work of our employees and sales team easier, we set out to simplify how users interact with Summarix‚Äôs structured data. Out of this ambition, Summy, our AI-powered chatbot, was born. 

We realized this project in close collaboration with SAP through the Early Adopter Care (EAC) Program for the SAP HANA Knowledge Graph Engine, a powerful extension of the SAP HANA database. In the following sections, we will share details of the Summy project, the challenges we encountered, and the technical decisions that shaped the solution. 

The Challenge 

Summarix already provided a user-friendly UI with filtering and search capabilities built on SAP Fiori, SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) and deployed on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) . While this approach worked well for simple questions, it did have several limitations:  

  • Filters could only cover what the product owners or developers had envisioned. 
  • Complex questions across multiple entities quickly exceeded the UI‚Äôs filter options. 
  • Aggregational queries (e.g., identifying the most experienced consultant in a skill or calculating the average years of experience over all consultants) were impossible with standard filters. 

In order to overcome these challenges and accelerate the search process, we envisioned a chatbot that would be capable of: 

  • Focus on information retrieval from structured data. 
  • Provide precise, single-turn answers to questions. 
  • Leverage new SAP technologies, particularly the SAP HANA Knowledge Graph Engine. 

This was also an opportunity for us to gain early hands-on experience with the Knowledge Graph Engine and to explore its potential.  

The Solution 

We implemented an innovative architecture built entirely on the SAP BTP. The system combines a knowledge graph and an agentic workflows to deliver precise answers to questions regarding the data stored in Summarix. 

‚ÄÉ

Key components of the solution: 

  • SAP HANA Knowledge Graph Engine: Stores data as a knowledge graph, facilitating SPARQL-based queries. 
  • SAP CAP backend: Manages orchestration, workflow logic, and query processing. While Python is a popular choice for many AI projects , we deliberately chose to integrate AI into our CAP (Node.js) backend using the SAP AI SDK. Utilising LangGraph.js and LangChain.js, we have modeled the agentic workflow directly in JavaScript. 
  • SAP Generative AI Hu: Provides access to LLM inference. We leverage its orchestration features and prompt templates, while retaining the flexibility to switch between models from OpenAI, Amazon, Google... 
  • Angular UI: A lightweight chat interface that runs as a shell plugin within the SAP Work Zone. 
  • Langfuse: Ensures observability and evaluation. This open-source tool enables us to trace executions, measure performance, and curate evaluation datasets. 

Key Features 

Our chatbot relies on an agentic AI workflow. While it is not a fully autonomous agent, the workflow defines a repeatable sequence of steps with conditional branches. This approach ensures consistency, reduces risks, and simplifies debugging, while still supporting dynamic, question-specific workflows and granting the agent some autonomy. 

Knowledge Graph Generation 

The project started with building the knowledge graph, which is based on the structured data from the SAP HANA Database of Summarix. This includes the following steps: 

  1. Export data from SQL into CSV. 
  1. Create graph nodes for entities (e.g., employees, projects, skills) with attributes while omitting irrelevant columns. 
  1. Model n-n relationships through connection nodes. 
  1. Export everything into Turtle (.ttl) files. 
  1. Ingest these files into the SAP HANA Knowledge Graph Engine. 

Ensuring data quality is paramount, as errors in this area can propagate through to the chatbot and significantly impact downstream task performance. As part of the ongoing development and implementation of improvements, the knowledge graph creation process has been repeatedly revised and enhanced . 

Entity Extraction and Matching 

Users naturally phrase questions in different ways (e.g., SAP BTP vs. SAP Business Technology Platform). Since each skill has a canonical name in Summarix, robust entity matching is required. 

Our approach, involved the following steps: 

  • Extract potential entities (skills, employees, projects and customers) from the question via an LLM using few-shot learning. 
  • Normalize entity names (singular form, multiple known variations). 
  • Search with regex-based case-insensitive filters for the existing entities. 

After matching the entities, we store them in the agent state for subsequent steps. 

SPARQL Query Generation 

After identifying the entities , the next step is to generate a SPARQL query. To guide the LLM, we did a lot of context engineering and provide: 

  • Context such as identity, instructions, and current date/time. 
  • The full ontology of the knowledge graph, including attributes and relationships. 
  • Detailed descriptions of all attributes, entities and relations. 
  • Examples of valid SPARQL queries. 

For this step, we (currently) rely on GPT-4.1 for its stronger reasoning capabilities, while lighter calls use GPT-4o-mini. 

We chose to use a knowledge graph approach, although it would also be possible to directly generate SQL and execute queries against the relational SAP HANA Cloud database. In our experiments, answers based on SQL queries showed slightly lower performance compared to those derived from the knowledge graph approach. 

Evaluation and Observability 

From day one,, we prioritized evaluation at inpeek to avoid a ‚Äúblack-box‚Äù development process and to establish clear KPIs and track their development over time. The key steps of our evaluation include: 

  • Curated a baseline dataset (~30 items) with questions and ground truth answers. 
  • Built an evaluation API endpoint to automatically rerun the dataset after each iteration. 
  • Use LLM-as-a-judge scoring (0‚Äì1) to assess the correctness of an answer compared to the ground truth answer. 
  • Introduced user feedback loops: flagged chatbot answers are added to new datasets, enabling continuous improvement based on previous incorrect answers. 
  • Track additional metrics, such as latency, costs and self-correction steps. 

Key Technical Considerations 

  • Multi-tenancy: Since Summarix is a SaaS product, we implemented our own multi-tenant logic to support different environments. So far , the SAP HANA Knowledge Graph does not offer multi-tenancy capabilites.  
  • Automated KG ingestion: A tenant-aware Python job daily updates the knowledge graph as data evolves in Summarix. 
  • CAP instead of Python: By keeping everything in CAP (Node.js), we simplified integration with authentication, lifecycle management, and SAP tooling. 
  • Context engineering: Providing a complete ontology with extended descriptions is crucial for reliable SPARQL generation. 
  • Evaluation-first approach: Systematic evaluation ensured objective improvements and prevented regressions.

Conclusion 

With Summy, we explored how the SAP HANA Knowledge Graph Engine can serve as a foundation for Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) on structured data. By combining knowledge graphs, SPARQL, LLMs and agentic workflows, we created a chatbot that can provide precise answers to complex business questions. This means consultants and sales reps can now answer tender-related questions in seconds instead of manually filtering data! 

This project demonstrated that success hinges on more than just the agent workflow, it also depends on data quality, entity mapping and evaluation pipelines. We had an excellent experience with the SAP HANA Knowledge Graph Engine and look forward to building on this foundation for future use cases. 

There is also a Medium blog post that delves deeper into the AI Engineering aspect, as well as a SAP Success Story highlighting the use of the knowledge graph for the chatbot and our SaaS solution, Summarix

If you‚Äôd like to learn more about this project or discuss AI in the SAP ecosystem, feel free to conntact us on LinkedIn: 

Fabian H√ºni (AI Engineer)
Fabian K√ºng (SAP Expert Consultant)

entry.title: SAP Joule Extensibility - With Joule Studio Skill Builder
entry.content:
During TechEd, AI was a central theme across nearly all sessions ‚Äî it was rare to find one where the term ‚ÄúAI‚Äù wasn‚Äôt mentioned. Many of these sessions focused on Joule agents, skills, and the Agent Builder, which is expected to be released by the end of December 2025.

That said, Joule Studio is already available today as part of Build Process Automation. In addition to the upcoming Agent Builder, it is currently possible to extend Joule‚Äôs capabilities using Custom Joule Skills through the Joule Skill Builder.

To put it simply, we are still running S/4HANA 2022 FPS02, and features such as Sales Order Fulfillment and Monitoring (SAP Note 3459573) via Joule are only available in later releases. As a result, asking Joule transactional questions related to Sales Orders does not yield any response.

Here‚Äôs where the Joule Skill Builder in Joule Studio comes into play.

We could create a custom skill and leverage existing BAPIs in the S/4HANA system. (First, a destination must be configured in the BPA BTP subaccount to establish the connection with the S/4 system.)

Once the S/4 system is accessible from BPA via this destination, the next step is to define actions‚Äîspecifying which fields, tasks, and data should be retrieved from S/4 using the relevant BAPIs (in this case, those related to Sales Orders).

The only mandatory input field required is the Sales Document Number; all other fields have been excluded from the selection.

The following are the only output fields (or outputs) of interest for this Joule Skill.

Once the Action is defined, we‚Äôre ready to build our first basic Joule Skill. I‚Äôll include a few numbered screenshots to illustrate the process and explain the overall flow.

 

Once the skill is deployed in your BPA environment, you can grant and share access to other users using the Share option. To test the skill, simply launch the standalone Joule using the Launch button.

The skill can also be deployed and made available to the central/shared Joule instance that is enabled across the SAP landscape, encompassing both private and public cloud systems and services (via Joule Formation).

Now we can retry the same Sales Order queries to check if Joule can provide meaningful responses. This time, I invoked Joule directly from our S/4HANA system, rather than launching it as a standalone instance from BPA.

Although this functionality is not natively supported in the S/4HANA version we are currently running, we successfully extended Joule‚Äôs capabilities by creating custom skills to address a simple, practical use case.

Disclaimer: An additional skill was also developed to demonstrate the Card with Buttons feature; however, it is not covered here üôÇ

Helpful Links

How to Get Started with Joule Studio

Set Up Joule Studio

Mission in Discovery Center

entry.title: SAP Joule Document Grounding (Business AI)
entry.content:
t‚Äôs finally time to explore Document Grounding and train Joule to answer questions using your company‚Äôs specific policy and knowledge documents. But before diving into Joule, it‚Äôs important to first understand Retrieval Augmented Generation.

 

  • Retrieval: When you ask a question, the system first searches a database, documents, or knowledge source (like a company‚Äôs files, research papers) for the relevant information.
  • Augmentation: Those retrieved documents are passed into the language model as extra context.
  • Generation: The model then uses both its own knowledge and the retrieved information to produce an answer that is more accurate and grounded in facts.

 

This helps reduce hallucinations (when an AI makes things up) and allows the model to answer questions about data it wasn‚Äôt originally trained on.

In line with the general SAP documentation approach, we used SharePoint as the content ingestion platform. This means that once you create and execute a data pipeline, documents from your selected SharePoint sites and folders are successfully ingested into the pipeline. After ingestion, Joule can leverage this information to augment its responses.

The setup is technically intensive. For those interested in testing this out‚Äîand to avoid overloading this post with technical jargon‚Äîthe SAP TechEd session on Setting up Joule to answer questions in your own policy documents is the best starting point.

We used Bruno as the tool to setup a data pipeline between SharePoint and BTP subaccount running Joule.

 

Below are a couple of examples where we set up a data pipeline to make Joule aware of Kardex (Kardex is an Automatic Storage Retrieval System). We also ingested specific HR policy documents.

As a result, when queried, Joule is contextually aware of this information and provides grounded responses specific to this knowledge base.

 

Be prepared for some issues and challenges during the deployment along the way and reference this great post " Joule ‚Äì Getting Started with Document Grounding"to solve some of them

Pre-Requisites for using Joule Document Grounding:

  • You‚Äôve purchased the AI Unit SKU (8019164) and AI units.
  • You‚Äôve added the entitlements for document grounding to the subaccount where you‚Äôve subscribed to Joule.
  • You‚Äôve enabled Identity Authentication with Cloud Identity Services

entry.title: New Machine Learning, NLP and AI features in SAP HANA Cloud 2025 Q4
entry.content:
With the SAP HANA Cloud 2025 Q4 release, several new embedded Machine Learning / AI functions  have been released with the with the Predictive Analysis Library (PAL), the Automated Predictive Library (APL) and the NLP Services in SAP HANA Cloud.

Key new capabilities to be highlighted include

  • A new unified time series procedure, serving developers to utilize the same interface across different times series algorithms
  • text embedding model enhancements, supporting output vector dimensionality reduction, while maintaining retrieval accuracy
  • a new cross encoder model with the NLP services, for accurately re-ranking search results
  • text column input, text embedding operators with AutoML classification and regression models
  • text tokenization enhancements supporting regular expression token filtering and a new text log parsing function for detecting and determining new log pattern
  • the HANA ML experiment monitor UI now supports visual model monitoring and drift analysis

An enhancement summary is available in the What‚Äôs new document for SAP HANA Cloud database 2025.40 (QRC 4/2025).

 

Time series enhancements

Introducing Unified Time Series interfaces

Unified time series is a newly introduced interface for a simplified use of multiple time series algorithms (ARIMA, Exponential Smoothing, Bayesian Structural Time Series (BSTS) and Additive Model Analysis (aka prophet)).

  • it allows for application developers to flexibly consume different time series analysis algorithms using the same procedure interface and a harmonized the handling of time series data patterns, avoiding algorithm-specific data preparation.
  • It also supports massive, data-parallel time series modeling for maximum parallelism and performance when modeling thousands of time series in parallel

 

A more detailed introduction to the new function is given in the following blog post https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/simplifying-time-series-analytics-with-unified-time-series-interface/ba-p/14292218

 

AutoML time series now support Prediction Intervals

AutoML time series predict function, in addition to all regular time series functions, now supports prediction intervals for probabilistic forecasting

  • the uncertainty associated with a forecast is quantified by providing a range (lower/upper bounds) into which a future observation likely falls with a specific confidence level.
  • For example a 95% prediction interval contains the true value 95% of the time

 

Text embedding model enhancements (NLP services)

Output vector dimension reduction

The Text Embedding models in SAP HANA Cloud have been enhanced with an attached a linear layer‚Äã‚Äã, derived from PCA trainings, to allow for the output vector dimensionality reduction

  • The arget dimension cardinality can be flexibly set to 128, 256 384, 512, 768 dimensions using ‚Äã‚ÄãPCA_DIM_NUM parameter
  • A near-original retrieval task accuracy is sustained with 256 dimensions, at 1/3rd of the original vector size (768 dimensions)
  • While lower dimension values than 128 would lead to significant and critical-level accuracy loss for retrieval tasks, hence 256 dimensions‚Äã‚Äã is recommended for efficiency & performance

Now text embeddings of significantly lower dimensionality can be utilized at a minimal information loss for retrieval tasks as well as machine learning.

Moreover smaller vector sizes unlock much faster machine learning processing times and may also serve vector retrieval queries

 

Text feature data support with AutoML models

Text column data and Text Embedding Operator in AutoML models

With the introduction of the a new text embedding operator for AutoML models, text columns can be directly used as input feature data and benefit from automatic, and optimized text vectorization utilizing SAP HANA Clouds text embedding models.

  • Text columns can be processed as feature, specified with the new parameter TEXT_VARIABLE
  • In addition, the new TextEmbedding operator supports the new target dimension reduction with the parameter PCA_DIM_NUM 
  • The enhancement are available with the SQL interface as well as hana-ml 2.27 in Python

With that, the semantic insights from text columns can get automatically unlocked when building AutoML classification / regression models.

 

Cross Encoder Model (NLP services)

Accurate re-ranking of search results

The family NLP services in SAP HANA Cloud has now been enriched with a new cross encoder model and respective PAL functions. The cross encoder model

  • Processes pairs/sets of text sentences (query, candidate results) together
  • Therefore allows for a more precise semantic similarity re-ranking of search results, based on the full contextual interaction analysis between the query and the input candidate set (e.g. a an initial result set retrieved from a vector engine similarity search)
  • Thus much higher accurate and relevant-ranked similarity search results can be achieved

 

Moreover the use of cross encoder models allows to combine multiple result sets retrieved from for example classic text search and vector engine similarity search queries into a hybrid search result, which can be passed into the cross encoder for its overall and combined re-ranking.

Custom AI, Retrieval Augmented Generation Applications (RAG) can now fully be served by Text Embedding Models, Vector Engine with Similarity Search and the Cross Encoder model, managing context privacy from the SAP HANA Cloud database.

 

Text tokenization enhancements and new automated log text analysis

Text tokenization support for regular expressions

The text pre-processing function Text Tokenize function for splitting input text into smaller units called tokens, has now been enhanced and supports regular expression for filtering token output patterns.

  • Custom filtering (removal/keeping) of text patterns can be applied
  • List of regular expressions, matching tokens will be kept / excluded
  • Typical filtering examples include extracting e-mail addresses, URLs, or other token patterns for domain-specific needs

 

Automatic pattern detection from log texts

A new analysis function for log text documents Text Log Parse has been added to the Predictive Analysis Library, which allows

  • For an automatic extraction of new log patterns and derive templates for new log patterns
  • High-performant processing of log texts for log classification and automated log analysis, the ability to detect and alert for new log patterns

 

 

ML experiment tracking and task scheduling enhancements

Experiment tracking enhancements

Tracking of experiments, now supports custom track entity tags

  • Standard track entities generated in PAL Training, Forecast, etc. can now be enriched with custom tags like business related information associated with related track entity
  • Tag is name-value pair for annotation or note, binding extra information to existing entities

 

A more detailed introduction is provided in the following blog post comprehensive-guide-to-mltrack-in-sap-hana-cloud-end-to-end-machine 

Moreover the Experiment Monitor in the Python Machine Learning client (hana-ml) supports for visually monitoring ML model performance degradation and drift.

 

One-off scheduling of PAL tasks

The PAL procedure scheduling interfaces has been enhance with a One-OFF schedule option, allowing for

  • ad-hoc, automatic one-off scheduled execution of PAL task procedures with dynamic setting of time-frequency information based on current UTC timestamp
  • it triggers a scheduled job to execute immediately, and the corresponding one-off schedule is removed right away and doesn‚Äôt require to be manually maintained.

 

Python ML client (hana-ml) enhancements

The full list of new methods and enhancements with hana_ml 2.27  is summarized in the changelog for hana-ml 2.27 as part of the documentation.  You can find an examples notebook illustrating the highlighted feature enhancements here 25QRC04_2.27.ipynb.

The key enhancements in this release include the following: 

Time series data outlier detection with threshold support

The method for time series outlier detection in the Predictive Analysis Library has added support outlier threshold settings, in addition to the outlier voting capability using different outlier evaluation methods incl.  Z1 score, Z2 score, IIQR score, MAD score, IsolationForest and DBSCAN

  • If the absolute value of outlier score is beyond the threshold, the respective data point will be considered as an outlier.

Time series reports for massive, data-parallel model scenarios

Massive AutoML Time Series modeling scenarios often utilize random-search with hyperband as the fastest optimization, potentially with larger number of time series data segment groups to be processed and forecasted in parallel, each time series segment group again with a significant number of forecast models to be explored. 

Hence the display of forecasts which have been explored by AutoML within each time series segment group is collapsed by default and can be expanded for review.

 

 

Classification and regression function enhancements

Support Vector Machine (SVM) model training is computationally expensive, and computational costs are specifically sensitive to the number of training points, which makes SVM models often impractical for large datasets.

The SVM algorithm now supports Coreset Sampling

  • which allows to automatically sample small, representative subsets (the "coreset") from larger datasets,
  • enabling faster, more efficient training and processing while maintaining similar model accuracy as using the full data.

This enhancement significantly reduces SVM training time with minimal impact on accuracy.

 

The model report for classification tasks now supports a percentage display in confusion matrix for easier visual interpretation of classification results.

 

High-dimensional feature data reduction using UMAP

UMAP (Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection) is a non-linear dimensionality reduction algorithm used to simplify complex, high-dimensional feature spaces, while preserving its essential structure. It is widely considered the modern gold standard for visualizing targeted dimension reduction of large-scale datasets, because it balances computational speed with the ability to maintain both local and global relationships.

  • It reduces thousands of variables (dimensions) into 2D or 3D scatter plots that humans can easily interpret.
  • Unlike comparable methods like t-SNE, UMAP is better at preserving global structure, meaning the relative positions between different clusters remain more meaningful.
  • It is significantly faster and more memory-efficient than t-SNE, capable of processing datasets with millions of points in a reasonable timeframe.
  • It can be used as a "transformer" preprocessing step in Machine Learning scenarios to reduce large feature spaces before applying clustering (e.g., k-means, HDBSCAN) or classification models, often improving their performance.

 

Calculating pairwise distances

Many algorithms, for example clustering algorithms utilize distance matrixes as a preprocessing step, often inbuild the functions. Often there is the wish to decouple though the distance matrix calculation from the follow-up task like the actual clustering. Moreover, if decoupled custom calculated matrixes can be fed into algorithms as input.

  • Most PAL clustering functions support to feed-in a pre-calculated similarity matrix

Now, a pairwise distance calculation function is provided

  • It supports distance metrics like Manhattan, Euclidien, Minkowski, Chebyshey as well as Levenshtein
  • The Levenshtein distance (or edit distance) is a distance metric specifically targeting distance between text-columns. It calculates the minimum number of single-character edits (insertions, deletions, or substitutions) needed to transform one word into another, acting as a measure of their similarity. A lower distance indicates a higher similarity.

Applicable use cases

  • It is useful in data cleaning, table column similarity analysis between columns of the same data type.
  • After calculating the column similarity across all data types, clustering like K-Means can be applied to group similar fields and propose mappings for fields within the same cluster

 

Again, an incredible set of enhancements in the SAP HANA Cloud database AI engine and NLP services!

Enjoy to try out all the enhancements and let us know what you think here!

entry.title: Hands-On Guide: SAP Build + Joule Skill for Purchase Order Listing, Approval, or Modification
entry.content:
Introduction

In this tutorial, we will build an AI powered Purchase Order listing, modification or approval app using SAP Build and Joule. This step by step guide covers everything from OData integration to creating a working Joule Skill.

 

Table of Contents

  • 1. Create an Environment
  • 2. Exposing the Destination
  • 3. Create a database table to store purchase orders
  • 4. Create a CDS from the ZTABLE for Odata
  • 5. Create OData service with T-code SEGW
  • 6. Activate the Odata service via /iwfnd/maint_service T-code
  • 7. Crete an Action in SAP Build
  • 8. Create A Joule Skill to Get Purchase Order
  • 9. Create A Joule Skill to Approve Purchase Order
  • 10. Launch The Joule and Test The Skills

 

 

In today‚Äôs SAP ecosystem, intelligent automation is an expectation, not a future goal. SAP Build allows developers to quickly create business applications without extensive coding and SAP Joule brings AI-driven intelligence to these experiences.

In this hands-on guide, I‚Äôll walk you through the process of building a Joule skill that connects to an OData service, allowing users to list, approve, and update purchase orders directly through SAP Build. ( This guide uses ZTABLE to store purchase order data because the standard SAP tables in the test system I work on don't have enough or the right kind of data. However, you can use the standard tables instead of ZTABLE. )

This project shows how AI capabilities can seamlessly integrate into SAP‚Äôs low-code environment, enabling automation and human decision-making in one interface. Whether you want to enhance your workflow with intelligent actions or explore real-world Joule integration scenarios, this guide will provide a practical starting point.

 

1. Create an Environment

 

We need to create an environment for testing joule skill.

Open the SAP Build Lobby, choose Control Tower->Environments and press the Create button.

 

 

Name your environment and add Description.

 

2. Exposing the Destination

 

Url of the destination on BTP is the url of our SAP system and the destination must have these properties: 

sap.applicationdevelopment.actions.enabled -> true

sap.processautomation.enabled -> true

sap.build.usage -> odata_gen

 

Also the destination‚Äôs user will be used for set an external break-point for debugging the ABAP code.

 

 

Open the SAP Build Lobby, choose Control Tower->Destinations and press the Add button.

 

Select the Destination and choose next.

 

Choose the environment in which you want to use the target. For this tutorial you can choose the Test Environment that you create.

 

3. Create a database table to store purchase orders

@EndUserText.label : 'Purchase Order Change With Sap Build'
@AbapCatalog.enhancementCategory : #NOT_CLASSIFIED
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #ALLOWED
define table zbg_build_test {
  key mandt                      : mandt not null;
  key purchaseorder              : ebeln not null;
  key purchaseorderitem          : ebelp not null;
  key reservationitem            : ebelp not null;
  material                       : matnr;
  materialcompisvariablesized    : boolean;
  materialcomponentisphantomitem : boolean;
  reservation                    : char10;
  @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure : 'zbg_build_test.entryunit'
  requiredquantity               : menge_d;
  requirementdate                : dats;
  reservationisfinallyissued     : boolean;
  baseunit                       : meins;
  @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure : 'zbg_build_test.entryunit'
  quantityinentryunit            : menge_d;
  entryunit                      : meins;
  plant                          : werks_d;
  latestrequirementdate          : dats;
  billofmaterialitemnumber       : ebelp;
  bomitemcategory                : char1;
  isbulkmaterialcomponent        : boolean;
  debitcreditcode                : shkzg;
  @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure : 'zbg_build_test.entryunit'
  withdrawnquantity              : menge_d;
  approver                       : uname;
  appoved                        : flag;

}

 

Fill the table:

 

 

4. Create a CDS from the ZTABLE for Odata

 

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSLV_BUILD_TST_V'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Purchasing Document Informations CDS'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.deleteEnabled: true
@ObjectModel.createEnabled: true
@ObjectModel.updateEnabled: true
define view ZSLV_V_BUILD_TEST as select from zbg_build_test as z 
    
{   @EndUserText.label: 'Purchase Order'
    key purchaseorder,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Purchase Order Item'
    key purchaseorderitem,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Reservation Item'
    key reservationitem,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Material'
    material,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Material Size'
    materialcompisvariablesized,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Material Item'
    materialcomponentisphantomitem,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Reservation'
    reservation,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Quantity'
    requiredquantity,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Date'
    requirementdate,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Reservation Issue'
    reservationisfinallyissued,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Unit'
    baseunit,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Entry Unit'
    entryunit,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Quantity In Entry Unit'
    quantityinentryunit,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Plant'
    plant,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Latest Requirement Date'
    latestrequirementdate,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Bill Of Material Number'
    billofmaterialitemnumber,
    @EndUserText.label: 'BOM Item Category'
    bomitemcategory,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Is Bulk Material'
    isbulkmaterialcomponent,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Debit Credit Code'
    debitcreditcode,
    @EndUserText.label: 'With Drawn Quantity'
    withdrawnquantity,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Approver'
    approver,
    @EndUserText.label: 'Approved'
    appoved 
    
}

 

5. Create OData service with T-code SEGW

(Because of the version of the system I work on, this guide uses SEGW instead of RAP to create an OData service. However, you can easily create your own OData service with RAP.)

Press ‚ÄòCreate Project‚Äô button, fill the fields and assign the package, request (For this tutorial it will be local object).

 

Complete the creation.

 

Extend the project, right click to ‚ÄòData Model‚Äô, select the Reference->Source

 

 

Fill the CDS name that you created. Choose ‚ÄòNext‚Äô.

 

 

Choose ‚ÄòFinish‚Äô.

 

 

Activate and generate the Service:

 

 

Go to the class ZCL_ZSLV_BUILD_DPC_EXT. At the bottom of the method list redefine the update method ZSLV_V_BUILD_TES_UPDATE_ENTITY.

 

 

In the method, update the approved field with the below code and activate it.

 

METHOD zslv_v_build_tes_update_entity.
 
  DATA: lv_ebeln TYPE ebeln,
        lv_ebelp TYPE ebelp,
        lv_item  TYPE ebelp,
        ls_entity TYPE zcl_zslv_build_mpc=>ts_zslv_v_build_testtype,
        lr_entity TYPE REF TO data,
        ls_table TYPE zbg_build_test.
 
  LOOP AT it_key_tab INTO DATA(ls_key).
    CASE ls_key-name.
      WHEN 'purchaseorder'.
        lv_ebeln = ls_key-value.
      WHEN 'purchaseorderitem'.
        lv_ebelp = ls_key-value.
      WHEN 'reservationitem'.
        lv_item = ls_key-value.
    ENDCASE.
  ENDLOOP.
 
  io_data_provider->read_entry_data( IMPORTING es_data = ls_entity ).
  MOVE-CORRESPONDING ls_entity TO ls_table.
  er_entity = ls_entity.
  UPDATE zbg_build_test FROM ls_table.
  COMMIT WORK.
 
ENDMETHOD.

 

6. Activate the Odata service via /iwfnd/maint_service T-code

 

Choose ‚ÄòAdd Service‚Äô

 

 

Select the ‚ÄòSystem Alias‚Äô, fill the ‚ÄòTechnical Service Name‚Äô and press ‚ÄòGet Services‚Äô. Select the service that you create and press ‚ÄòAdd Selected Services‚Äô.

 

 

Assign the package and continue.

 

 

We have added the service, which should appear as follows. In the ICF Nodes section, there is a button labeled "SAP Gateway Client" that provides a testing environment for the service. Press that button.

 

 

Select the HTTP method as ‚ÄòGET‚Äô. Press ‚ÄòEntitySets‚Äô to choose entity set. Choose the one that you created.

 

 

Press ‚ÄòExecute‚Äô button for testing and response should appear as follows.

 

 

7. Crete an Action in SAP Build

 

Open the SAP Build Lobby, choose Connectors->Actions and press the ‚ÄòCreate‚Äô button. Choose ‚ÄòOData Destinations‚Äô and select the Destination that we created.

 

 

Fill the Resource Path as follows and click ‚ÄòNext‚Äô.

 

 

The available methods are listed in this window. Select ‚ÄòNext‚Äô.

 

 

Fill the name and description for your action and create.

 

 

The action Purchase_Order_Action is created. Click the action and open it.

 

 

Select the methods in the OData Service.

 

 

The GET method's input has no required fields, only optional GET parameters.

 

 

Output parameters are the fields in the CDS that we created. 

 

 

Methods can be tested in the action interface. For the GET method we don‚Äôt need to fill any input parameters. Click ‚ÄòTest‚Äô button.

 

 

The data appears on the ‚ÄòTest Preview‚Äô section.

 

 

The PATCH method requires purchaseorder, purchaseorderitem and reservationitem, all of which are key fields in our ZTABLE and CDS.

 

 

There are no standard output in PATCH method.

 

 

In the Test section, all required fields and fields that need to be changed must be filled out. In this scenario these fields are purchaseorder, purchaseorderitem, reservationitem and approved fields.

 

Also the link on the Test section can be used in the SAP Gateway Client to test the PATCH method.

 

 

 

PATCH method return ‚Äú204: NO CONTENT‚Äù and empty Response. This means the update is successful and we will use this emptiness in our joule skill.

 

 

After checking and testing, save the methods using the ‚ÄòSave‚Äô button and select ‚ÄòRelease‚Äô. After the release process, the action should appear as shown below. Then, press 'Publish'.

 

 

You can debug when testing methods via the SAP Gateway Client or the SAP Build Action. Set an external breakpoint for the user in your destination that we created at the beginning.

 

 

For the PATCH method, our key fields in the internal table IT_KEY_TAB. 

 

 

8. Create A Joule Skill to Get Purchase Order

 

Open the SAP Build Lobby, choose Create->Joule Skill and fill the name and description. Open the created skill.

 

 

Select the ‚ÄôTrigger‚Äô step. On the ‚ÄòGeneral‚Äô tab fill the name and description. Allow Joule to generate a response and skill to be started directly by user.

 

 

We don't need input, but outputs can vary according to our needs. In this tutorial, the parameters shown below have been added as outputs.

Choose ‚ÄòConfigure‚Äô and add parameters you want to show to the user. For this example, all parameters are string except the ‚Äòapproved‚Äô which is boolean.

 

 

 

Press ‚Äò+‚Äô and choose ‚ÄòCall Action‚Äô, ‚ÄòBrowse All Actions‚Äô.

 

 

Search for ‚ÄòZSLV_V_BUILD_TEST‚Äô or your Service Name. Add the ‚ÄòGet entities from ZSLV_V_BUILD_TEST‚Äô.

 

 

Select the ‚ÄòDestination Variable‚Äô as Destination we created. 

 

 

We can skip the input tab because there are no input for GET method.

 

 

We can see the output parameters in this tab.

 

 

On the "End" step, we need to assign the input and output parameters for the skills. Since we don't have any inputs, let's assign the outputs added in the "Trigger" step as our action's outputs.

 

 

Save the Joule Skill.

 

 

And Release.

 

 

Now Deploy.

 

 

Choose the Environment we created and click ‚ÄòUpgrade‚Äô.

 

 

Match the destinations, and the skill will be ready to use by Joule after deployment.

 

 

9. Create A Joule Skill to Approve Purchase Order

 

On the ‚ÄòTrigger‚Äô step, fill the name and description. Deactivate the ‚ÄòAllow Joule to generate a response‚Äô feature because in this skill we will create our own messages. The other feature should be active.

 

 

Configure the input parameters. Add purchaseorder, purchaseorderitem and reservationitem key fields as string. For approve skill we don‚Äôt need any output field.

 

 

Choose ‚Äò+‚Äô and ‚ÄòCall Action‚Äô.

 

 

Browse All Actions.

 

 

Search update or the service name. Add the Update entity in ZSLV_V_BUILD_TEST.

 

 

On the ‚ÄòGeneral‚Äô tab, assign the Destination.

 

 

On the ‚ÄòInputs‚Äô tab, assign the purchaseorder, purchaseorderitem and reservationitem to the parameters created on the "Trigger" step.

 

 

We only need to fill the fields ‚Äòapproved‚Äô from the fields to be updated. We need to configure the ‚Äòapproved‚Äô field because action inputs can only be string. 

 

Choose ‚Äòapproved‚Äô field and ‚ÄòApply a formula‚Äô.

 

Type ‚Äòtrue‚Äô and click ‚ÄòApply‚Äô.

 

 

Choose ‚Äò+‚Äô and ‚ÄòCheck Condition‚Äô.

 

 

Choose the ‚ÄòCondition Editor‚Äô.

 

 

Add the following conditions and Click ‚ÄòApply‚Äô. If PATCH method is executed successfully, the result will be empty. 

 

 

If the condition is met, the left branch of the condition executes. In the opposite case, the ‚ÄòDefault‚Äô branch of the condition executes.

 

Choose the ‚Äò+‚Äô on the left branch and ‚ÄòSend Response‚Äô.

 

 

Open Message Editor.

 

 

Fill the parameters as shown below and save.

 

 

You can add parameters to the title and message with the ‚Äò<>‚Äô button.

 

 

Do the same steps for the right branch of the condition. ‚Äò+‚Äô -> ‚ÄôSend Response‚Äô -> ‚ÄòOpen Message Editor‚Äô

 

Fill the parameters as shown below and save.

 

 

Save, Release and Deploy just like the previous GET_PURCHASE_ORDER skill.

 

10. Launch The Joule and Test The Skills

 

Open the SAP Build Lobby, choose Control Tower->Environments->Joule

 

 

Launch the joule, ask for Purchase Orders and get the details.

 

 

Ask joule to approve the purchase orders and get the illustrated success message card we create.
